simulator.framework
Class AbstractTimer

java.lang.Object
  simulator.framework.AbstractTimer
All Implemented Interfaces:
FutureEventListener
Direct Known Subclasses:
SystemTimer, Timer
public abstract class AbstractTimer
extends java.lang.Object
implements FutureEventListener

Allows elevator modules to schedule themselves to execute at specified times in the future. Such modules must implement TimeSensitive. When a Timer is created, it is associated with a TimeSensitive object called the "handler". When the handler calls start(jSimPack.SimTime), it specifies a time interval after which this Timer "expires". When this Timer expires, it will call the handler's TimeSensitive.timerExpired(Object) method. This Timer does not automatically repeat; the handler must call start after each time timerExpired is executed. If a handler creates more than one Timer, it can distinguish between their calls to timerExpired by specifying different callback objects to the #start(long, Object) method of each Timer. This abstract class can be implemented on different time bases by subclassing and specifying the scheduleEvents() and cancelEvent() methods

Constructor Detail

AbstractTimer

public AbstractTimer(TimeSensitive handler)
Constructs a Timer with the specified handler. When the Timer expires, it will call back to the handler's timerExpired(Object) method.

Method Detail

scheduleEvent

protected abstract FutureEvent scheduleEvent(FutureEventListener event,
                                             SimTime timeInterval,
                                             java.lang.Object data)
Schedule the timer event - this method is implemented to schedule the Timer on a specific event queue.

Parameters:
event - Event to be scheduled
timeInterval - Amount of time in the future to schedule the event
data - Callback data for the timerExpired callback
Returns:
the event object that was created. This can be used to cancel a timer event.

cancelEvent

protected abstract void cancelEvent(FutureEvent event)
Cancel a pending event - this method is implemented to cancel Timer events on a specific event queue.

Parameters:
event - event to cancel

setVerbosity

protected static void setVerbosity(int verbose)
Sets the logging verbosity for all Timer objects.

Parameters:
verbose -

start

public void start(SimTime startTime)
Schedules this Timer to expire after the specified time interval has passed. When it expires, it will pass null to timerExpired.

Throws:
java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if nanoSeconds is negative

start

public void start(SimTime timerDuration,
                  java.lang.Object callback)
Schedules this Timer to expire after the specified time interval has passed. When it expires, it will pass callback to timerExpired. The timer does not automatically repeat. You must call start() every time you want to use the timer.

Throws:
java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if nanoSeconds is negative

isRunning

public boolean isRunning()
Returns true if and only if the Timer is scheduled to expire.

cancel

public void cancel()
Stops the Timer so it will not call back to the handler. If the Timer is not running, this method does nothing.

public java.lang.String toString()

eventReleased

public void eventReleased(java.lang.Object data)
Description copied from interface: FutureEventListener
Invoked when an event is released from a FutureEventList. The argument is whatever was passed as the data parameter when jSimPack.FutureEventList#schedule(FutureEventListener, long, Object) was called to register this event.

Specified by:
eventReleased in interface FutureEventListener
